P106708.project_name: CO DPL on Promoting an Inclusive, Equitable and Efficient Social Protection System

keywords.cdata: administrative structure, aggregate demand, aging, amortizations, basic services, Beneficiaries, bonds, Borrower, budget support, budget support operations, capacity building, capital accumulation, Capital Expenditures, capital formation, cash transfer, Cash Transfers, Central Bank, central Government, consolidation process, consumption smoothing, contingent liabilities, credit growth, Credit Line, CURRENCY, current account deficit, cyclical policy, Debt, Debt Sustainability, decentralization, decision-making, democratic processes, Development Bank, DEVELOPMENT POLICY, disasters, Disbursement, disbursements, domestic demand, Economic Developments, economic downturn, economic growth, efficiency gains, entitlements, Evaluation Capacity, Exchange Rate, Expenditure, Expenditures, export growth, external debt, external financing, external shocks, families, family support, Family Welfare, Financial Accountability, financial assets, Financial Management, financial sector, financial sectors, financial services, financial sustainability, financing requirements, Fiscal consolidation, fiscal costs, fiscal impact, fiscal policy, fiscal policy framework, fiscal pressure, fiscal pressures, fiscal sustainability, flexible exchange rate, flexible loan, Foreign Direct Investment, fraud, global economy, Government expenditure, grace period, gross debt, Gross Domestic Product, Gross National Product, health care, health financing, health insurance, health programs, health services, human capita

project_abstract.cdata: The Colombian economy is facing the impacts of a sharp aggregate demand contraction, but sound macroeconomic policies implemented in recent years have substantially improved the country's economic resilience against crisis. In the near term, economic activity is likely to reverse its decline and the Bank's base scenario for Colombia includes gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 0.4 percent in 2009 and a modest rebound of economic activity in 2010. Despite the impact of global conditions, Colombia is in a better position to confront the global crisis than other Latin America and Caribbean (LAC) countries, as a result of its countercyclical monetary policy and fiscal stimulus over 2009. While there remains uncertainty as regards to the depth and length of the global recession, neither external nor fiscal sustainability appear at risk. The operation proposes to consolidate past gains and support the reform agenda in areas that need strengthening and consolidation. The development objective of the operation is to strengthen an inclusive, equitable and efficient social protection system by: (1) promoting greater integration, efficiency and equity of social insurance, (2) improving the targeting, efficiency, and articulation of social assistance programs, and (3) promoting higher quality training and employment services. To achieve this objective, the operation supports policies in a broad range of areas, in particular: 1) efforts to increase the coverage of inclusive systems serving the entire population such as the national training and labor intermediation system or health insurance; 2) efforts to build an equitable system that serves the poor and vulnerable through improved targeting and coordination of social assistance and greater efforts to reach the poorest; 3) and efforts to increase the efficiency of social protection through improved information systems, ration
